Pullman Strike

People’s Party Convention

Air Traffic Controllers go on strike in biggest disaster in organized labor’s history.
Creation of the Bracero Program.
Nat Turner’s Rebellion.
Execution of Sacco and Vanzetti
Founding of the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters
Rock Springs Massacre
Tobacco workers win contract in North Carolina, starting CIO’s Operation Dixie campaign.
International Woodworkers of America Local 3-101 holds a monthly union meeting
Joe Hill executed in Utah
Thibodaux Massacre
Ratification of the 13th Amendment.
Creation of the Colored Farmers Alliance
President Kennedy issues Executive Order 10988, authorizing collective bargaining for public workers
March on Washington Movement leads to end of official segregation in defense industry.
Cripple Creek gold miners strike
Grover Cleveland signs the Dawes Act.
Sons of Vulcan win nation’s first union contract
Supreme Court rules in Oncale v. Sundonwer Offshore Services. Same-sex sexual harassment.
River Rouge march and repression.
Coalition of Labor Union Women holds first meeting.
Truman nationalizes steel industry.
OSHA begins
Wisconsin passes first workers compensation law
Chinese Exclusion Act
Kader Toy Fire.
Anthracite coal miners strike in Pennsylvania begins, TR mediates
Battle of the Overpass.
Paterson Silk Pageant
here
Davis Day
Eugene Debs arrested for violating Espionage Act.
Molly Maguires executed in Pennsylvania
Denmark Vesey executed for planning slave revolt in South Carolina.
Port Chicago explosion
Frank Little lynched in Butte.
Wheatland Riot
invention of electric washing machine transforms women’s unpaid domestic labor.
FDR signs Social Security Act.
Air Line Stewardesses Association, first flight attendant union, forms.
Battle of Blair Mountain
Boston police go on strike, crushed by Massachusetts governor Calvin Coolidge.
Lattimer Massacre
Iron Workers bomb Los Angeles Times building.
Closing of Storyville, New Orleans’ red light district.
John Brown launches attack on federal arsenal at Harpers Ferry, Virginia in order to gather guns to free slave labor.
Erie Canal opens after over 1000 workers die building it.
Nicholas Farwell’s hand is crushed working on railroad, courts decide in Farwell v. Boston and Worcester Rail Road Corporation that companies have no responsibility for working conditions.
Cherry Mine Fire in Illinois kills 259 workers.
WTO protests begin in Seattle.
American Federation of Labor founded in Columbus
Curt Flood sends letter to Major League Baseball demanding free agency.
Federal Coal Mine Health and Safety Act signed.
Ellis Island opens.
German Coast slave rebellion begins in Louisiana.
Tompkins Square Riot.
Publication of Looking Backward.
Ralph Chaplin writes “Solidarity Forever.”
Lowell Female Labor Reform Association organizes and forces Massachusetts to investigate conditions in the Lowell textile mills.
Theodore Roosevelt and Japanese government agree to Gentlemen’s Agreement, ends most Japanese immigration to the U.S. after west coast labor protests
Pittston Coal Company slurry dam collapses in Logan County, West Virginia, 125 dead.
Davis-Bacon Act signed.
LaFollette Seamen’s Act signed
Lordstown Strike
Salt of the Earth premiers
Postal Workers go on strike
Founding of Republican Party, free labor ideology
Police tear gas strikers at Hormel plant in Austin, Minnesota
Toledo Auto-Lite strike begins.
Bunker Hill Mining Company in Idaho announces policy of sterilization for women working in its lead smelter
Works Progress Administration created.
Hard Hat Riot
Completion of Transcontinental Railroad, treatment of Chinese workers
Coolidge signs Immigration Act of 1924
Normal Rockwell publishes Rosie the Riveter cover in Saturday Evening Post
Celia, a slave, kills her master when he attempts to rape her
FDR signs Fair Labor Standards Act
IWW founded
Phelps-Dodge strike starts in Clifton-Morenci, Arizona, massive union-busting by copper company
FDR signs National Labor Relations Act
Southern Tenant Farmers Union forms in Tyronza, Arkansas
Watertown Arsenal workers strike over Taylorism
United States Commission on Industrial Relations formed
Eisenhower signs Landrum-Griffin Act
Lincoln issues Emancipation Proclamation
Richard Nixon announces Philadelphia Plan to desegregate construction industry
Henry George accepts United Labor Party nomination for mayor of New York
John L. Lewis punches Carpenters president Big Bill Hutcheson on the floor of the AFL Convention.
Donora Fog
Invention of cotton gin.
Spokane free speech fight begins.
Mississippi institutes its Black Code
Union Carbide plant leak at Bhopal, India
Alabama repeals child labor law to attract New England textile factories.
Italian Hall disaster in Calumet, Michigan
Henry Ford announces $5 day for workers who lived a lifestyle of which he personally approved
End of the International Nestle Boycott
Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo signed, fate of New Mexican land grant labor
Kate Mullaney and Collar Laundry Union go on strike in Troy, New York
Muller v. Oregon decided
Hoover Dam turned over to government. Labor history of its construction.
Knights of Labor begin Great Southwestern Strike against Jay Gould’s railroads
New York Times first reports Radium Girls story.
Paris Commune begins
Mother Jones arrested supporting Colorado coal strike.
Mine explosion in Centralia, IL kills 111 workers.
AFSCME goes on strike in Atlanta, crushed by mayor Maynard Jackson
Workers Rights Consortium founded in New York
Supreme Court decided Lochner v. New York
Franklin Delano Roosevelt creates Tennessee Valley Authority
Poor Person’s March starts its camp construction in Washington DC.
Cananea Strike in Mexico, prelude to Mexican Revolution
Los Angeles police beat SEIU members in Justice for Janitors march
CIA-led Guatemalan coup against Jacobo Arbenz begins with AFL support
Herrin Massacre
Supreme Court decides Industrial Union Department AFL-CIO v. American Petroleum Institute, limiting OSHA workplace health program
International Labor Organization passes Freedom of Association Convention. U.S. never ratifies it.
Steelworkers Strike of 1959 begins
AFL-CIO refuses to endorse George McGovern for president
President Carter declares Love Canal a federal emergency
Panama Canal opens, story of its workers
National Labor Union demands Congress implement the 8-hour day
The March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom
Christiana Riot, runaway slaves resisting Fugitive Slave Act
Black Monday in Youngstown
Comanche defeated at Palo Duro Canyon, end of a work history
George H.W. Bush signs Radiation Exposure Compensation Act
Newark sweatshop fire kills 25 workers
AFL endorses federal unemployment insurance, turning its back on history of voluntarism
Theodore Roosevelt sends U.S. Army to crush IWW strike in Goldfield, Nevada.
Moses Brown hires Samuel Slater to build a modern textile mill in Pawtucket, Rhode Island, beginning the United States’ Industrial Revolution.
Assassination of Brazil rubber tapper union leader and environmentalist Chico Mendes
Skylab astronauts go on one-day strike
Lettuce workers go on strike in Imperial Valley, starts era of farmworker organizing
Pinkertons kill 14 year old boy at Jersey City coal wharves’ strike
OCAW strike against Shell, assisted by environmental groups
Gold discovered in California, idea of white labor in the West
Yale graduate students go on strike
FDR nominates Frances Perkins to be Secretary of Labor
Film adaptation of The Grapes of Wrath released
Hawk’s Nest tunnel project in West Virginia starts, leading to mass deaths from silicosis
End of the Civil War
FDR orders Montgomery Ward to accept union or face government seizure after it refuses to recognize union
Land for Drop City purchased, a window into the counterculture and work
The Johnstown Flood
Child Labor Amendment passes Senate, sent to states where it is not ratified
Speculator Mine disaster in Butte, Montana kills 168 workers
Leadville Strike
Salem Fire and workplace safety
Civil Rights Act of 1964, including Title VII
The Philippine Scouts, Filipino soldiers in the US occupying army of their homeland, strike
Bonus Army encampment burned
Newark leathermakers lock out employees to destroy the Knights of Labor
Peterloo Massacre in Manchester
Haitian slave revolt begins
Hamlet, North Carolina chicken factory burns, kills 25 workers
North Carolina governor calls out National Guard to bust textile strike
Avondale Colliery fire, 110 miners die
Farm Labor Organizing Committee signs contract with Mt. Olive Pickles and its contracting farmers
Fourth IWW convention begins, Daniel DeLeon’s Socialist Labor Party loses bid to take over organization
West Coast ports close because of lockout, George W. Bush invokes Taft-Hartley to open them 10 days later
Farmers kill two strikers at Pixley, California
-Lyon silk weavers revolt
President Carter signs the Pregnancy Discrimination Act
U.S. Army occupies South Carolina sea islands, start of Port Royal Experiment
United Fruit workers in Colombia go on strike, government responds with massacre

New York State Education Commissioner reasserts state control over Ocean Hill-Brownsville school district, ends major conflict over the Ocean Hill-Brownsville teachers strike led by Albert Shanker over black community control
opening of Pins and Needles at ILGWU Labor Stage
Darr Mine fire in Pennsylvania kills 239 workers
Emma Goldman deported
Hurricane Creek Mine Disaster kills 38 miners near Hyden, Kentucky
Carl Mackley Homes, housing development created by the Hosiery Workers’ Union, opens in Philadelphia
Oral arguments before SCOTUS conclude in Moyer v. Peabody that state National Guard can imprison citizens without habeas corpus
Oahu Sugar Strike begins
Japanese Mexican Labor Association forms
Loco Foco rally leads to Flour Riot
Navajo appeal against livestock reduction program
Norris-LaGuardia Act passes Senate
Tydings-McDuffie Act signed, granting the Philippines independence because Californians were angry that these workers were marrying white women
Mexican government arrests and imprisons railroad strike leaders
Julius and Ethel Rosenberg convicted
Loray Mill Strike in Gastonia, North Carolina begins
Hershey sit-down strike begins
Supreme Court decides Adkins v. Children’s Hospital, striking down federal minimum wage for women
Florence Kelley begins her work with the National Consumers League
Local 1199 begins hospital workers strike in New York
Panic of 1837 begins
Catharine Beecher, author of Treatise on Domestic Economy, which created ideological framework for modern housework, dies
National Industrial Recovery Act introduced into the House
Disney cartoonists go on strike
Slaves executed as part of New York Slave Conspiracy
Civilian Vocational Rehabilitation Act approved by Congress
Teamsters for a Democratic Unionism formed
Workers at Rodolfo Crespi cotton mill in Sao Paulo demand 25 percent wage increase, refusal leads to Sao Paulo general strike
Steel Workers Organizing Committee formed
Washington Arsenal explosion kills 20 workers
Three timber workers killed in Eureka, California during Great Strike of 1935
Ralph Gray, communist and leader of Croppers and Farm Workers Union in Tallapoosa County, AL murdered by white mob
Tennessee forces surrender to miners during Coal Creek War to keep convict laborers from competing with miners
Alexander Berkman shoots Henry Clay Frick
Grunwick Strike begins in England, defeat of which started the Thatcherite attack on unions
NOW leads Women’s Strike for Equality
Pittsburgh textile strike begins
Panic of 1873 begins
24 fired women picket the Lindstrom Tool and Toy Company in Bridgeport, CT after they are fired from their wartime jobs because they are women
Two are killed in Lee County, Arkansas during battle between Colored Farmers Alliance members and other cotton workers
Col. Brice Disque named to lead Spruce Production Division, a government effort to send soldiers to Northwesters forests as loggers and destroy the IWW
Baltimore seamstresses go on strike, discussion of white women workers in the antebellum period
Prisoners at Ellis Prison in Texas refuse to pick cotton for no wages
OSHA fines American Cyanamid $10,000 for coercing women into sterilization, followed by OCAW lawsuit
Woodrow Wilson signs the Clayton Act
Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union forced JP Stevens to sign a contract for the first time in the Carolinas and Alabama, ending 17-year campaign
AFL-CIO Convention begins that leads to victory of John Sweeney, revitalizing the federation
Congress approves the Reorganization Acts Amendment that lay the groundwork for the creation of the Environmental Protection Agency, how EPA helps working people.
Illinois executed four innocent men for the Haymarket bombing
Colorado governor sends militia to crush Cripple Creek strike
Battle in Clearfield County, Pennsylvania over an attempt to break a coal strike, a vision into the early coal mines and miner culture
Baptist War in Jamaica, slave rebellion that moves British toward emancipation
Zapatista Rebellion begins in Chiapas, Mexico, timed with the implementation of NAFTA.
Augustus Hawkins introduces HR 50, becomes Humphrey-Hawkins Act
General William Tecumseh Sherman issues Special Field Order No. 15 for freed slaves, giving them 40 acres and a mule
Founding of the United Mine Workers of America
Environmentalists storm the gate of International Paper in Jay, Maine during strike that was dominated by unsafe working conditions and pollution
US Steel signs first contract with Steel Workers Organizing Committee
New York City subway strike begins and James Farley breaks it with record speed, gaining fame as the era’s most notorious strikebreaker
Sao Paulo’s metalworkers strike, with Lula as a leader; over 3 million workers go on strike, a massive challenge to the Brazilian dictatorship
Luddite movement begins in England
Soviet military forces crush Kronstadt Rebellion
Supreme Court decides UAW v. Johnson Controls, ruling that a company banning women from working in hazardous jobs was a discriminatory act
Supreme Court decided the case of West Coast Hotel Company v. Parrish, upholding the constitutionality of state minimum wage laws
Arguments begin in NLRB v. Mackay Radio & Telegraph Company
New York slave revolt of 1712
Texas City disaster kills at least 581 people, the largest workplace disaster in American history
Juan de Villarroel files the first mining claim at Potosí, Bolivia, beginning a long history of exploitation of indigenous labor there
FDR authorizes seizure of coal mines after UMWA refuses National War Labor Board arbitration
Abolition of slavery in Brazil
Treaty of Detroit between GM and the United Auto Workers
UFW comes to agreement with the Bruce Church lettuce company, ending 17-year boycott
Massachusetts establishes its minimum wage commission to create the nation’s first minimum wage
16 workers at Memphis’ Buckeye Cotton Oil Company go on wildcat strike for discrimination on job
Congress passes Espionage Act
Flight attendants win lawsuit against United Airlines for firing them after getting married as far back as the 60s
Workers at Nissan plant in Smyrna, TN reject UAW representation by 2:1 margin
Frances Perkins speech at Homestead, PA when she is cut off by Homestead government
Family and Medical Leave Act goes into effect
London Great Dock Strike begins
New York City theater owners and actors sign agreement ending strike over bad conditions
workers return to work after victory in IWW-led Pressed Steel Car Company strike at McKees Rocks, Pennsylvania
AFL-CIO Solidarity Day to protest Reagan
T.A. Gillespie Shell Loading Plant near Sayreville, New Jersey exploded, killing approximately 100 workers
Workers at Brown and Sharpe factory in North Kingston, Rhode Island begin the longest strike in American history
Katsu Goto, a Japanese organizer in Hawaii, is murdered
Sit-down strike at Hormel plant in Austin, Minnesota begins
New Orleans general strike ends
Columbine Massacre in Colorado coal strike
Ybor City cigar manufactures ban reading in the factories, leading to strikes
House passed what becomes Employment Act of 1946
Kansas National Guard breaks up women’s marches to support coal strike
400 women in Dover, NH go on strike in their mill, possibly first all-female strike in American history
Sharecropper contract signed between landowner Isham Bailey and freedmen
strike of electrical workers in Saigon just before the Tet Offensive shows the weakness of the South Vietnamese government
Lucy Parsons leads an unemployed march of 10,000 in Chicago
Spanish troops begin their attack on Acoma Pueblo, window into labor relations in colonial New Mexico
The Senate failed to gain cloture on an attempt to appeal Section 14(b) of the Taft-Hartley Act
Hoedads working in Oregon poisoned, countercultural reforestation labor
The Panic of 1893 begins when the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad goes bankrupt
Shoemakers in Lynn, Massachusetts begin the nation’s largest strike before the Civil War
Agricultural Workers Organizing Committee is created
The workplace health and safety reformer Alice Hamilton is born
CA farmworker march from Delano to Sacramento
California passes An Act for the Suppression of Chinese Houses of Ill Fame
Textile Workers Union v. Darlington Manufacturing decided, case that limits collective bargaining over plant closures to effects from a single plant closing
U.S. President Martin Van Buren issues an Executive Order ordering the 10 Hour Day on federal projects
West Virginia Mine War of 1912 begins
Furniture workers go on strike in Grand Rapids, many over the objections of their churches
USWA men beat Mine, Mill president Maurice Travis, costing him an eye
Chicago 8-hour day strike
Milwaukee police kill 7 workers during 8-hour day strike
Maraka noble killed by slave in Mali as part of slave exodus in region
Jury finds for Karen Silkwood’s estate over her murder five years earlier
Supreme Court overrules Keating-Owen Child Labor Act in Hammer v. Dagenhart
Greenback Party convention nominates presidential candidates
Case against laborers in England over wages after Black Death
Winnipeg General Strike ends
Alabama stops leasing of convicts to mine coal
Streetcar workers in New Orleans go on strike
Denver smelter strike and the creation of the foundational principles of the IWW
end of first black Chicago bus drivers wildcat strike infused with Black Power politics
Raid on sweatshop in El Monte, California uncovers 72 Thai workers in slave labor conditions
Worker fired that leads to Solidarity movement in Poland
International Longshore and Warehouse Union (ILWU) created
South African mineworkers strike
planned date for Gabriel’s Rebellion
Brotherhood of the Union founded
Election of Allende and impact on Chilean labor
Watsonville Cannery Strike begins
Gray Davis signs first paid family leave law in US
Bread riot in Fall River as striking textile workers forced to return to work
Battle of Virden
RICO Act becomes effective
First of five workers die at Standard Oil’s Bayway TEL works from lead exposure in making leaded gasoline
Operation Breadbasket, SCLC attempt to boycott businesses that don’t hire African-Americans
Jeon Tae-Il, a Korean sweatshop worker, burns himself to death in protest over the sweatshop conditions of he and his fellow workers
-Cuban cigar workers strike in Tampa collapses
John Henry taken from Richmond prison to blast railroad tunnel
Monongah Mining Disaster in West Virginia kills at least 362 workers
Teamsters expelled from AFL-CIO
Farmers converge on England, Arkansas to demand poverty relief, leads to Will Rogers poverty tour
Durban, South Africa wildcat strikes that was first significant unrest since sentencing of Mandela in 1964
NYC transit strike led by Mike Quill ends
Brooklyn trolley strike starts
Allis-Chalmers strike
